title: Thursday, 19th November, 2015

11:13 am
PM

here's some Barclays

PM

Prospects for an imminent rise in US interest rates need not undermine stock prices.

Sentiment took a beating in the late summer selloff and we now know non-resident investors were very heavy sellers: history shows positive returns from such episodes.

Global growth of 3.4% next year, and an expected removal of the Oil price drag, should mean earnings growth recovers to 7% in 2016.

Most global valuation measures are "in-line" or slightly below historical norms, and therefore no barrier to performance if the earnings are forthcoming. Indeed the global market is cheaper now than at the start of previous US tightening cycles.

We do think Fed policy could impact leadership within the market. In the past, higher rates have favoured value over quality and growth, while inhibiting the performance of early cycle cyclicals, such as Consumer Discretionary.

Higher US rates and superior EPS growth should also encourage leadership amongst non-US equities.

PM

Actually, ive gone and opened their 2016 PDF

11:14 am
PM

Dopeople want all these year ahead notes in the usual place?

PM

can do if you like

PM

And some Credit Suisse

11:15 am
PM

The long-expected interest rate divergence between the US and euro area is finally taking hold. Policy statements and commentary by officials over the last month provided the requisite spark, signaling that truly divergent policy actions– via easing from the ECB and tightening by the Fed – are imminent.

Under our base case – a Fed hike in December followed by three next year, an ECB cut in December and an open door to further easing – policy action will drive the divergence narrative next year. The BoE, meanwhile, looks likely to be caught in the middle, sitting tight and let its trading partners diverge away before starting to raise rates in August 2016.

PM

In rate space, we view the 5-year point as optimal for those looking to set US-Germany yield spread wideners, but acknowledge that there are risks to the policy divergence theme in rates – notably that resulting FX moves (USD strength, EUR weakness) could curtail the extent of true policy action needed.

In the US, we frame our forecast discussion in the context of China slow-down and inflation speed-up risk scenarios. We maintain our preference for front-end steepeners – this week we recommend a June/July 2016 FOMC meeting OIS steepener– and long-end flatteners. We discuss core inflation dynamics, finding no obvious signs of significant upside risks from a bottom-up perspective, though the top-down analysis looks somewhat more encouraging. We also note that the recent widening in cross-currency bases is not entirely due to year-end dynamics, and we highlight scope for further widening.

PM

Recent ECB rhetoric reinforces our view that the ECB will cut the deposit rate further into negative territory at the December meeting. We discuss curve implications if the ECB over- or under-delivers vs. the 10bp cut currently priced. Since Draghi has removed the floor for European interest rates, with inflation and inflation expectations so low, the outlook for policy rates has become asymmetrical. With the market likely to price for further cuts, we continue to like being long Schatz. German swap spreads, however, look stretched in our view, and we continue to recommend being short Bobl ASW.

Just like the MPC is reluctant to pull the trigger and follow the Fed in raising rates while the ECB is still easing, gilt investors should think twice before getting underweight in their portfolios. We favour a tactical approach to trading duration into 2016, with a bias to buy on dips. On the curve, a cautious MPC will limit the degree to which 2y rates will sell off, and so 5y will be the weak spot instead.

11:15 am
PM

And Citi

PM

So there you have it—the majority of the FOMC says they will be ready to begin
normalizing rates in December.

PM

 As for the biggest obstacle to raising rates, the October FOMC discussion
suggested they became more confident that inflation would rise to its target in the
"medium term." The FOMC assessed the aftermath of the September turbulence
and dismissed its impact on the US (so what was that fuss in September?). Also,
they recalled concerns about financial stability risks from prolonged low rates.

11:16 am
PM

Some participants, however, judged it unlikely that the information available by the
December meeting would warrant raising the target range for the federal funds rate
at that meeting. Nevertheless, it seemed clear that more hawkish sentiment for
starting normalization prevailed

PM

The main job for the FOMC in December and beyond is to convince financial
markets that the pace of rate increases will be much slower than in past cycles. We
believe that the FOMC's data dependent policy has made it much more difficult to
define "gradual" and credibly ensure its delivery. We believe that the Fed's path of
rate increases will begin in December, but will not reach above two percent until
2018.

PM

The Fed plans to continue reinvesting its portfolio of Treasury and agency MBS
assets until sometime after the first few rate hikes. The FOMC has not made any
explicit decision about the optimal long-run size of the balance sheet. No matter
what the Fed decides on the long-run optimal size of the portfolio, it will be years
before we expect to see the new equilibrium size for the balance sheet.

11:16 am
PM

Once the Fed ends reinvestments, government funding that had been provided by
the Fed will now need to be supplied by the private market.
 The Fed’s persistent bid for agency MBS has been a key factor keeping spreads to
Treasuries at tight levels. For Treasuries, the market impact of the Fed ending
reinvestments depends on how Treasury responds with increased issuance.
 Following first rate hikes fixed-income markets are likely to pay more attention to
issues around the Fed’s portfolio and the speed at which the Fed normalizes rates.

PM

Done

http://www.investe...1511190700092275G/

PM

Ah, ok

11:18 am
BE

Clearly, the guidance is awful

PM

"The sales comparables in the second half are softer and our Christmas range is our best ever. However, we have seen highly volatile trading conditions so far in the third quarter. The quarter's performance therefore depends more than ever upon the last six weeks' trading towards Christmas.'

PM

"Fingers crossed"

11:19 am
BE

Yeah, the 99p stores it bought are lossmaking. Considerably.

BE

Not helped by suppliers pulling credit insurance.

BE

Which is something we haven't seen for a while, though it was a fun theme during the last days of HMV, Jessops and the like.

11:20 am
BE

Here's Cazenove's new forecasts.

BE

Poundland has reported a 19% decline in interim EBITDA to £16.8m, 5%
below our estimate. It has identified an incremental EBITDA opportunity
from the integration of 99p Stores of ‘at least £25m’ in due course. 99p Stores
is currently performing worse than expected, though. We have lowered our
EBITDA estimate for FY2016 by 15% as a result of the loss expected from
99p Stores, but increased FY2017 by 23% and FY2018 by 22% as we include
the acquisition for the first time.

BE

 H1 FY2016: An eventful period for Poundland. Poundland completed its
£55m acquisition of 99p Stores during the period. During the half, it also
battled tough comps to deliver -2.8% LFL growth and opened an unusually
high number of stores (52). The negative LFLs and higher pre-opening costs
incurred by Poundland pulled interim EBITDA down 19% y/y to £16.8m,
5% below our estimate of £17.7m. Underlying PBT was £9.3m, 27% lower
than H1 FY2015 and 10% below our estimate.
 99p Stores: The good news. Poundland has identified incremental
EBITDA of ‘at least £25m’ from 99p Stores. This is expected to come from
an improved sales performance as the stores are converted and start to trade
as Poundland. It is also expected to accrue from the synergistic benefits of
greater scale in the coverage of overheads and procurement.
 99p Stores: The bad news. 99p Stores is performing more poorly than
anticipated at the time of the acquisition. Poundland expects 99p Stores to
realise a £6-8m EBITDA loss in H2 FY2016. The poor performance was
exacerbated by a withdrawal in credit insurance (now fully restored since the
acquisition), which has affected seasonal stock levels.
 Changes to estimates. We have included 99p Stores in our estimates for the
first time. We assume a £7m EBITDA loss from 99p Stores in H2 FY2016,
resulting in a group EBITDA estimate that falls 15% from £61.9m to
£52.6m (we have lowered our underlying estimate for Poundland by 4%).
The inclusion of 99p Stores drives 23% and 22% higher EBITDA estimates,
respectively, in FY2017 and FY2018. Forecast EPS rises by 3% in FY2017
and 8% in FY2018.

11:21 am
BE

And Morgan Stanley.

BE

Bottom line: Weak set of numbers which should not surprise investors given
the pre-announcement last September. Similar to B&M on Tuesday,
management is flagging the volatile trading conditions providing very limited
visibility on FY results – we expect consensus to come down 4-5% today.
Topline performance: Poundland reported sales for the 14 weeks to
September 20th on September 24th so today's results only include an
additional week of trading. The group LFLs were down 2.8% in the first
semester in line with the 2.9% decline reported for the first 25 weeks of
F1H15/16e . Similarly, sales on a constant currency basis increased by +5.6%
in F1Q15/16, in line with the +5.5% reported last September.
Store network expansion: Poundland opened 52 net new stores by the end
of F1H15/16 (6 stores in F1Q), in line with management guidance of 70 net
new stores in FY15/16e in the UK and Ireland, implying selling space
expansion of 17% in F1H15/16.
Margins: Gross margin decreased by 20bps to 36.3% (in line with consensus)
due to the decline in the mix contribution of own labels and the weak Euro.
EBITDA margin decreased by 90bps to 3.0% (consensus 3.2%) due to the gross
margin decline and the higher pre-opening costs. Consequently, the group
EBITDA decreased by 18.5% to £16.8m (consensus £17.5m) and group PBT fell
by 26% to £9.3m (in line with consensus).
99p Stores update: Poundland provided an update on the 99p Stores
business which suffered some trading disruption during the CMA investigation
period and is now expected to post an EBITDA loss of £6-8m in F2H15/16e.
However, they are seeing good sales uplifts on the first 99p stores that have
been converted and they plan to have most stores converted by April 2016.
Moreover, they have identified £25m incremental EBITDA as they transfer the
99p Stores portfolio to the Poundland estate.

BE

Current trading and outlook: Management highlighted that trading
conditions have been volatile since the beginning of the determinant
F3Q15/16 and the quarter's performance therefore depends more than ever
upon the last six weeks' trading towards Christmas.
Valuation: Based on last night’s closing price and existing consensus
forecasts, Poundland is trading at 17.1x cal 2016 earnings, 10.4x EBITDA and
2.1% dividend yield. This compares to the UK General Retail sector on 15.3x,
8.8x and 3.3% respectively.

Johnson Matthey PLC (JMAT:LSE): Last: 2,657, up 200 (+8.14%), High: 2,709, Low: 2,579, Volume: 1.28m
PM

http://www.investe...1511190700052096G/

11:25 am
PM

Special divi

BE

Big rally. Clearly a lot of risk previously in the price post VW's issues.

BE

Yeah, special is the surprise. Trading's not great.

11:26 am
BE

You're getting a 150p special from a disposal, which is about 50p higher than where the consensus was I think.

BE

Other than that, I'm struggling to see any positives.

BE

Jefferies is reassured, under the circumstances.

11:27 am
BE

In line 1H16 results, FY group guidance consistent with existing consensus and
delivery of a 150p special dividend as we looked for a reassuring update post
recent market concerns.
1H results as expected at the group level, though did include a stronger EBIT contribution
from ECT (+£13m ahead of consensus) that offset a lower contribution from PT (£11m
behind consensus). Working capital (the negative surprise the FY15) improved by £386m.
Sales:£1588m JEFe:£1574.4m Consensus:£1590.6m Diff vs consensus: -0.2%
PBT:£208.3m JEFe:£205m Consensus:£208.9m Diff vs consensus: -0.3%
EPS:86.3p JEFe:84p Consensus:85.74p Diff vs consensus: 0.7%
DPS:19.5p JEFe:19.3p Consensus:18.87p Diff vs consensus: 3.3%
150p per share special dividend announced - consistent with JEFe that had hoped
for 148p.
Guidance looks consistent and still points to underlying growth: Guidance is for
FY performance to be similar yoy (excluding businesses sold) – this is a slight change in the
way this has been communicated before (previously given on a reported basis). We estimate
last year PBT excluding units sold was c.£415m. Research Chemicals contributed £38m of
revenue into FY16 before sale, so at an estimated 20% margin, maybe £7-8m of EBIT. Add
also some of the newly announced cost savings (£30 million p.a. starting in 4Q – mainly in
PT) and consensus (for FY16 PBT £423.5m) looks to have been given little reason to change
materially. Indeed, the group states "the full year outlook for the group is in line with current
market expectations." That said, the weight of refill catalyst orders within PT timed for 4Q is
a risk for the year. Also, cost savings are steered to result in a £40m exceptional 2H charge
(of which £35m is expected to be cash). Within all of that, further exclude the £15m (largely
non-cash) underlying increase in pension costs expected to be absorbed into the divisions
across the full year and the headwind of market pgm price declines for the Refining and
Recycling activities and the group's flat guidance seems to us to continue to assume some
solid underlying growth. The group anticipates growth for FY17.

BE

Commentary on diesel - although it may be too early to have expected to see any impact,
no change has yet registered on diesel penetration, which at 51% of 1H LDV production
in Europe 1H16, compares to 50% 1H15. And there is no change in group views that
“We continue to expect diesel's share in Western Europe to gradually trend down due to the
continuing fuel efficiency improvements in gasoline engines.” And….”we still believe diesel will
remain an important part of the mix going forward.” Further commentary notes that new
“not to exceed” NOx limits will require more robust NOx control after treatment systems
on diesels and that Johnson Matthey is confident it has the technologies to meet new
legislation. Tightening of emissions requirements should continue to present opportunity
for the catalyst providers, in our view.
Valuation - on our forecasts, we estimate Johnson Matthey trades at 14.8x/13.9x March
16/17 eps vs peers averaging 17.2x/15.6x.

BE

Joe Spooner is the analyst.

11:28 am
BE

And Morgan Stanley.

BE

ECT performing well as other divisions deteriorate further: For Q2
'15/16, JM has reported underlying PBT of £114.3m, in line with consensus of
£114.9m and lower than our more aggressive £120.3m. For H1 '15/16 we'd
suggest JM's results were essentially in line, with sales excluding PGMs of
£1,588m almost exactly in line with cons. of £1,591m and EBIT of £225m just
1% below cons. of £228m, with adjusted EPS of 86.3p again in line. Fears
around deteriorating fundamentals in PT (oil & gas and China slowdown) and
PMP (weaker PGM pricing) were well founded, with divisional EBIT in H1
across both segments falling 24% and 10% respectively below cons.
expectations. However, as has been the case persistently over recent years, ECT
continues to exceed expectations (Euro 6b legislation), delivering EBIT for the
period of £136m, nearly 11% better than cons. of £123m. So, the misses in PT
and PMP (and to some extent Fine Chemicals driven by weaker API activity)
were fully offset by strength in ECT and lower Corporate charges relative to
expectations.

BE

Restructuring and special dividend announced (as expected on the
latter): Weaker trading conditions outside ECT have triggered JM to start a
restructuring programme, especially in PT. The target is to reduce annual costs
by £30m, which will result in one-off charges of £40m (£35m of which is cash).
Savings are expected to start filtering through in Q4 of the current financial
year. As earmarked earlier in the year, JM has now formalised its special
dividend, paying 150p (£305m) on top of its 19.5p interim dividend. As
flagged by the company before, the special dividend will be funded out of the
£380m of gross proceeds from selling Gold & Silver Refining and Research
Chemicals.

11:29 am
BE

Guidance suggests little change to consensus expectations: JM has said
its outlook for the year remains consistent with market expectations.
Consensus is expecting FY '15/16 underlying PBT of £424m, which we think is
deliverable. Divisional guidance also supports this, with ECT in H2 expected to
be similar to H1 (i.e. EBIT of ~£136m in H2, which is higher than cons. of
£112m), PT to be sequentially higher due to project ramps (so we'd suggest
~£40m EBIT in H2, but this is much lower than cons. of £64m), PMP to be
down in H2 sequentially (so we'd suggest H2 EBIT of £32m, way lower than
cons. of £45m) and Fine Chemicals to be up sequentially (i.e. to around £43m
in EBIT in H2 we think, in line with cons. of £44m). So, a clear message – ECT
strength is mitigating weakness in the other 3 segments relative to
expectations.

BE

Bottom line... there's likely to be some relief in the shares today, we think,
given there are no immediate cons. downgrades likely. Although the special
dividend was expected, this should also help drive some relief in the shares
now it has been formalised. However, one word of caution as we look forward:
JM's business is firing on one cylinder right now, with ECT strength likely to
come under increasing scrutiny given fears around global automotive growth
and future developments in the US truck market. Nonetheless, we'd expect the
shares to outperform today. We're EW.

BE

so, yeah, bounce and probably a bit of a short squeeze. Though I don't have the loan data to hand so that's a guess.

11:29 am
PM

fair enough

PM

11:31 am
BE

PM

Bovis Homes Group PLC (BVS:LSE): Last: 909.50, down 79.5 (-8.04%), High: 919.00, Low: 860.00, Volume: 1.35m
11:31 am
BE

Even though there's no obvious readthrough for the sector.

Barratt Developments PLC (BDEV:LSE): Last: 576.00, down 1.5 (-0.26%), High: 579.50, Low: 572.00, Volume: 1.47m
Berkeley Group Holdings PLC (BKG:LSE): Last: 3,090, down 49 (-1.56%), High: 3,150, Low: 3,089, Volume: 199.09k
11:32 am
Taylor Wimpey PLC (TW.:LSE): Last: 185.00, down 0.7 (-0.38%), High: 187.00, Low: 184.00, Volume: 4.16m
PM

London house prices definitely coming off the boil -- in the 1m-2m range

PM

Aksing prices are being cut

11:32 am
BE

Sure, though the listed housebuilders have relatively little exposure to London.

BE

With the exception of Berkeley.

PM

This is Markets LIve

11:33 am
BE

Anyway, Bovis is a good old-fashioned veiled profit warning.

BE

They appear to be making market consensus until you get to the bit about margins.

BE

Which will be "only marginally ahead of the prior year"

11:34 am
BE

Why? Well, their reasons are everything and nothing.

BE

Including planning delays on higher margin sites and cost pressures.

BE

Barclays reckons this is Bovis making a mess of things.

11:35 am
BE

That no other house builders have cited these planning delays as a material issue (or in most cases a minor issue) points to a company-specific issue. Indeed, this follows a number of other disappointments in recent years, including:

· The trading update in July 2015, which pointed to the legal completion profile in 2015 being ‘more weighted to the second half’.

· 2015 H1 numbers were boosted by land sales.

· 2014’s operating margin (17.0%) was itself a disappointment, with the company guiding to ‘between 17% and 18%’ as recently as last August.

· 2014’s volumes (3,635) came in below the 3,650-3,850 range guided to in May of the same year.

In addition, the general tone from other house builders has suggested that build cost pressures have been diminishing, rather than increasing, in recent months.

BE

Market conditions remain very supportive. With recent updates from Crest Nicholson and Taylor Wimpey reaffirming that trading conditions remain supportive, we see little, if any, read-across to others here. Indeed, the company’s sales rate (0.62 sales per site per week) since the beginning of September is up 20% versus the corresponding period of last year, suggesting that underlying market conditions remain robust.

Put simply, what Bovis appears to be telling us is that it has few problems selling homes, just not ones that deliver full margins.

BE

Capital turn to rise to ‘over one times’. We highlight some brighter news on capital turn (itself somewhat perplexing, given the planning delays) with the company expecting this to rise to ‘over one times’. Although this is a reiteration of previous comments (which appeared at the interim stage), this has been a key source of weakness – as a key component of its return on average capital employed (currently the lowest in the sector), this positive news is tempered by the disappointment on the other component of the calculation, operating margins.

We see nothing here to suggest that the company will relinquish its status as the lowest-returning house builder under our coverage, based on our definition of return on capital employed

11:36 am
PM

ha

BE

Likewise Deutsche, which sees Bovis as the outlier rather than the lead indicator.

BE

Against a tide of positive results in the sector, Bovis trading update feels like a
cold shower. FY 15 profitability impacted as planning delays push back
completions on its new higher margin sites, although for FY 16 mgmt indicate
the increasing build costs should be offset by a greater mix benefit to selling
price. Trading at 1.25x 2016 NTAV Bovis is the cheapest stock in the sector,
and against bottom end of peer ROCE this is hard to dispute (although dividend
yield is becoming increasingly interesting). However for those willing to believe
the group can drive towards the 28% ROCE on new land, any weakness as
consensus reshuffles following this update could prove a buying opportunity.

11:37 am
BE

1) Robust trading continues. Bovis reports that sales have strengthened into
autumn, with a sales rate since the start of September +20% (excluding PRS)
to 0.62 reservations per site, with the group 38% sold for next year (+18%).
2) But margin impacted by planning delays on newer sites: DB PBT ests
reduced by 6% in FY 15. While Bovis reports it has reservations that cover its
planned 8% growth in completions for 2015 (DB ests were 10%), and an
average sales price for 2015 in line with guidance (+ 7%), delays in planning
and therefore completions on its newer higher margins sites have reduced
upside in margins YoY. Reflecting this change in margin guidance we have
reduced our PBT est for FY 15 by 6%. For FY 16 management indicates that
while the contribution of the new higher margins sites should be captured
the upwards creep of build cost inflation (upped from 7% to 7-8%) implies a
smaller upside in gross margin YoY than previously indicated. Management
believes this downside to margin expectations should be largely offset by a
higher than consensus average selling price driven by mix. However while
management has retained its target for

20% ROCE in FY 16, and believes

there should be little movement in consensus for next year, we have reduced
our FY 16 PBT by 8% (moving in line with consensus). 3) Land acquisition
slows, but discipline continues. To date Bovis reports it has added 25 sites (c
4,000 plots), and while this is equivalent to replacement it remains short of
the 40 new sites targeted. Management indicates that there remains scope
to reach its target by YE, although it highlights that progress has been
slowed by the uncertainty created by the change in social rent. The group
reiterates however that there remains no shortage of opportunities in the
land market, and discipline remains (an av ROCE of land in 2015 of c28%).

BE

We set our price target at 1.5x 2017E NTAV discounted back at 8% plus
dividends paid out to this date. Downside risks include: lower margins made
on the new land, lower volumes seen to leverage Bovis' operational costs.

BE

Buyers. £13.22 target.

11:37 am
undefined
PM

BE

11:38 am
BE

BE

BE

Anyway, what else?

11:39 am
PM

PM

PM

11:39 am
PM

PM

Royal Mail PLC (RMG:LSE): Last: 479.20, up 25 (+5.50%), High: 484.50, Low: 470.10, Volume: 2.99m
11:40 am
BE

PM

Ah, cost control

BE

Yup. Targets on the cost savings have been raised.

11:40 am
PM

BE

Which I assume means sacking people. It may also mean selling off stuff I guess. Perhaps to housebuilders.

BE

Anyway, we get another £500m of targeted savings.

11:41 am
PM

Transformation costs increased, reflecting higher levels of voluntary redundancy costs. Nearly 3,000 (net) UKPIL employees left the business in the first half.

PM

yes, sacking posties

BE

Or the way they phrase it, 70 "scoped and resourced projects across UKPIL" to reduce £500m of additional annualised costs by 2017-18.

11:42 am
BE

Because, clearly, Royal Mail in its current state is a flabby and overstaffed organisation. That's why it takes an hour to pick up a parcel from the sorting office.

BE

Caz can take us through the detail here.

BE

RMG delivered a solid FH1 result on slightly better than expected group
revenue and GLS profitability. Mail volume upside more that offset parcel
price/mix downside while accelerated transformation is driving an upgrade to
FY16 core cost base guidance (along with a rise in associated costs). The
overall market growth outlook is unchanged while RMG also announced
£500m of targeted cost ‘avoidance’ by FY18 vs. £200m achieved the past
three years (mitigating inflation). Valuation: CY15E 11.2x adjusted P/E and a
FCF yield of 6.6% or 9.6x and 7.7%, resp., ex. estimated real estate value.

11:43 am
BE

 Adjusted EBIT before transformation costs 2% better than expected or
£342m vs. JPMe £334m. That’s 3% and 5% ahead of the company-provided
consensus mean median, resp. (see Tables below). On the back of £4.4bn
group revenue (flat y/y, same as FQ1), this implies a margin of 7.8% (flat
y/y) vs. our 7.6% estimate. Adjusted EPS of 18.1p was 3% light vs. JPMe as
actual transformation costs of £94m exceeded our £78m on accelerated
headcount reduction. Net debt stands at £369m. The interim 7.0p/share
dividend is in-line with expectations.

BE

 Re-attained Whistl volumes lift postal revenue trend… to -3% y/y in
FH1 vs. -4% in FQ1 as volumes declined by -4% vs. -5% in FQ1 with no
apparent change to the implied price/mix contribution of +1% over the
period. In the past, RMG noted a c. £20m annualized EBIT impact from
Whistl direct delivery volumes.

BE

 …Mitigating softer parcel revenue growth development of +1% in FH1
vs. +2% in FQ1 despite accelerated volume growth to +4% y/y vs. +3%.
This suggests a harsher price/mix headwind of -2% in FH1 vs. -1% in FQ1
owed to the same factors cited by RMG in the past: competition and a higher
mix of lower-yielding import volumes.
 Strong GLS revenue and volume growth trends unchanged with resp.
+8% and +9% y/y growth in FH1 (same as FQ1). Italy delivered doubledigit
volume growth while overall margin pressure was lower than expected.
 Guidance raised for UKPIL costs and GLS margins. Underlying FY16
UKPIL costs are now expected to decline by at least 1% vs. flat-to-down
previously (JPMe c.-1.5%) while guided y/y GLS EBIT margin pressure is
now seen at the better end of the 50-100bps range. The UKPIL upgrade
reflects accelerated transformation and related costs now seen at £180m for
FY16 vs. £120-140m previously (JPMe £128m).

BE

The pension position remains an overbearing weight on the company's medium-term
ability to generate sustainable cash flows. Royal Mail currently pays c£400m in cash
pension costs from a total requirement of c£700m agreed at the time of the last pension
review. The difference (so £300m p.a.) has been funded through a surplus created from
an agreement between unions, RMG and the trustees to cap final salaries at RPI rather
than RPI+1%. Low current bond yields means the likely pension costs is now closer to
£900m (according to RMG) and the surplus will be drawn down by 2018. For now, there is
no obvious lever RMG can pull to avoid higher cash pension costs being incurred at the
time of the next review. The schedule of contributions for the next five years need to be
agreed by June 2016. One scenario could be using cash generated from the disposal of
property assets to close some of the gap but visibility remains low for now which
represents a key risk for medium-term investors.
